subject: Re: JUnit automatically
msgSnippet: ... Good questions J.B. I did not start this thread, and I don t know Shivam, but I felt compelled to answer since we are talking about our company s product
messageBody:
>How does a computer know what kinds of tests I need to write?
>How does a computer know what the expected results are?

Good questions J.B.

I did not start this thread, and I don't know Shivam, but I felt
compelled to answer since we are talking about our company's product
Agitator, and I want to avoid misconceptions.

As you might guess, Agitator cannot know the expected results - only
the developer can know that. What Agitator can do for you is
generate test data that gets you code coverage and then shows you
what it observed in the form of class and method invariants. These
observations are in the form of Java boolean valued assertions. For
example:

File.canWrite() == true

Or
File.getPath().equals("C:\foo\bar")

Or
File.list().length == 14

The developer looks at these observations and if they match the
expected results they can check a box and turn that into an
assertion - the equivalent of writing "assertEquals(14,
File.list.length)" in Junit, for example.

If the observations don't match the expected behavior, the developer
can modify them. For example, if the number in the last assertion
was supposed to be 17 instead of 14, the simply edit the observation
and then "promote" it into an assertion:

File.list().length == 17

Or the developer can create new assertion to associate with the
method.

Combined with Agitator's ability to automatically generate very
relevant test data and achieve very high code coverage automatically
(through data flow analysis and other dynamic techniques), automated
observations are a powerful and very efficient way to create unit
tests quickly to get the developer to consider inputs and conditions
that they might have missed. But the developer input is still
required to decide if what Agitator observed is what the code is
suppsed to do.

I'll stop here because I don't want to use this forum to promote
Agitator, but I wanted to clear any misconceptions and answer J.B.'s
questions.

If you want to learn more about our Agitator and our experiences
with this new way to approach unit testing you can check out:

www.developertesting.com/

Thanks,

Alberto
